items.title: US hits ICC with more sanctions, targets French judge involved in Netanyahu arrest warrant
items.standfirst: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday announced more sanctions on International Criminal Court judges, saying that the court was a "national security threat" because it had sought to prosecute US or Israeli nationals. Judge Nicolas Guillou of France, who is presiding over a case in which an arrest warrant was issued for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, was among those sanctioned.
items.content: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday announced more sanctions on International Criminal Court judges, saying that the court was a "national security threat" because it had sought to prosecute US or Israeli nationals. Judge Nicolas Guillou of France, who is presiding over a case in which an arrest warrant was issued for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, was among those sanctioned.

items.title: US expands sanctions targeting International Criminal Court
items.standfirst: United States expands attacks on International Criminal Court amid growing scrutiny over Israeli abuses in Gaza.
items.content: United States expands attacks on International Criminal Court amid growing scrutiny over Israeli abuses in Gaza.

items.title: Israel set to approve settlement project that could divide the West Bank
items.standfirst: Israel on Wednesday gave approval for a controversial settlement project in the occupied West Bank’s E1 area, a move Palestinians and rights groups warn could effectively block a future Palestinian state. The development, long frozen under US pressure, has been backed by far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich as a challenge to Western countries recognising a Palestinian state. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israel on Wednesday gave approval for a controversial settlement project in the occupied West Bank’s E1 area, a move Palestinians and rights groups warn could effectively block a future Palestinian state. The development, long frozen under US pressure, has been backed by far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich as a challenge to Western countries recognising a Palestinian state. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details from Jerusalem.

items.content: Israel on Wednesday approved a major settlement project in the West Bank, despite warnings from the international community that doing so threatens the viability of a future Palestinian state.

items.content: Israel will call up 60,000 reservists as it prepares to launch an expanded military operation in Gaza City.

items.title: Israel enters first stage of planned assault on Gaza City
items.standfirst: TEL AVIV — Israel on Wednesday entered the first stages of a planned assault on Gaza City after approving a plan to take it over that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for an expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.
items.content: TEL AVIV — Israel on Wednesday entered the first stages of a planned assault on Gaza City after approving a plan to take it over that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for an expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.

ai_summary: Israel initiated a military operation to seize Gaza City, the largest urban center in the enclave.
Sixty thousand reservists have been called up to bolster the ongoing military operation.
Attacks on Gaza have killed 81 people amid a humanitarian crisis.
The United States imposed sanctions on the International Criminal Court, drawing criticism.
Prime Minister Netanyahu praised the US sanctions on the International Criminal Court.

clusters.title: Trump admin. can end deportation protections for Honduras, Nepal and Nicaragua
clusters.neutral_headline: Court Allows Trump to End Migrant Deportation Protections

items.title: Trump admin. can end deportation protections for Honduras, Nepal and Nicaragua
items.standfirst: An appeals court has cleared the way for the Trump administration to end deportation protections for over 60,000 people from Nicaragua, Honduras and Nepal — at least for now.
items.content: An appeals court has cleared the way for the Trump administration to end deportation protections for over 60,000 people from Nicaragua, Honduras and Nepal — at least for now.

items.title: US court allows Trump to end temporary protections for 60,000 migrants
items.standfirst: Appeals court pauses an order that had protected status for Nepalese, Hondurans and Nicaraguans.
items.content: Appeals court pauses an order that had protected status for Nepalese, Hondurans and Nicaraguans.

items.title: Donald Trump Scores Court Win as Protections Blocked for 60,000 Migrants
items.standfirst: The Trump administration has already ended Temporary Protected Status for more than a million immigrants.
items.content: The Trump administration has already ended Temporary Protected Status for more than a million immigrants.

items.title: US court allows Trump officials to end protected status for 60,000 migrants
items.standfirst: Administration officials given legal right to move towards deportation of people from Nepal, Honduras and NicaraguaA federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court’s order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.This means that the Republican administration can move toward removing an estimated 7,000 people from Nepal whose temporary protected status designations expired on 5 August. The TPS designations and legal status of 51,000 Hondurans and 3,000 Nicaraguans are set to expire 8 September, at which point they will become eligible for removal. Continue reading...
items.content: Administration officials given legal right to move towards deportation of people from Nepal, Honduras and NicaraguaA federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court’s order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.This means that the Republican administration can move toward removing an estimated 7,000 people from Nepal whose temporary protected status designations expired on 5 August. The TPS designations and legal status of 51,000 Hondurans and 3,000 Nicaraguans are set to expire 8 September, at which point they will become eligible for removal. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A court ruled in favor of the Trump administration regarding deportation protections.
The ruling allows the administration to end protections for 60,000 migrants.
Protections for migrants from Nepal, Honduras, and Nicaragua are affected.
The TPS designations for Nepalese migrants expired on August 5.
The TPS designations for Hondurans and Nicaraguans expire on September 8.

items.content: Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard is slashing her office's staff by roughly 40% — the latest major Trump-era change slated for the intelligence agency.

items.title: Tulsi Gabbard revokes security clearances of 37 US intelligence officials
items.standfirst: The director of national intelligence accuses the officials, who served under Biden and Obama, of politicising intelligence for partisan or personal gain.
items.content: The director of national intelligence accuses the officials, who served under Biden and Obama, of politicising intelligence for partisan or personal gain.

items.title: Gabbard announces 40% cut to workforce at key U.S. intelligence office
items.standfirst: The Office of the Director of National Intelligence will dramatically reduce its workforce and cut its budget by more than $700 million annually, the Trump administration announced Wednesday.
items.content: The Office of the Director of National Intelligence will dramatically reduce its workforce and cut its budget by more than $700 million annually, the Trump administration announced Wednesday.

ai_summary: Tulsi Gabbard is cutting the staff of the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.
The workforce will be reduced by approximately 40 percent.
The budget of the office will be cut by over $700 million annually.
The cuts are the latest major Trump-era changes to the intelligence agency.
Gabbard accuses officials of politicizing intelligence for partisan gain.

items.standfirst: Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth and White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller were heckled ...
items.content: Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth and White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller were heckled ...

items.title: JD Vance booed during hamburger handout to national guard troops in DC
items.standfirst: US vice-president, at Washington’s Union Station with Stephen Miller and Pete Hegseth, defends use of troops in area with less crimeJD Vance was booed and heckled with chants of “Free DC!” during a photo op with national guard troops at Union Station in Washington on Wednesday afternoon.Handing out burgers to troops deployed last week by Donald Trump, at the station’s Shake Shack alongside the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, and White House deputy chief of staff, Stephen Miller, Vance told soldiers “we appreciate everything you’re doing” and asserted: “We brought some law and order back.” Meanwhile, a crowd of demonstrators protested outside. Continue reading...
items.content: US vice-president, at Washington’s Union Station with Stephen Miller and Pete Hegseth, defends use of troops in area with less crimeJD Vance was booed and heckled with chants of “Free DC!” during a photo op with national guard troops at Union Station in Washington on Wednesday afternoon.Handing out burgers to troops deployed last week by Donald Trump, at the station’s Shake Shack alongside the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, and White House deputy chief of staff, Stephen Miller, Vance told soldiers “we appreciate everything you’re doing” and asserted: “We brought some law and order back.” Meanwhile, a crowd of demonstrators protested outside. Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: JD Vance heckled as he meets National Guard in Washington DC
items.standfirst: Protesters shouted at Vance, Pete Hegseth and Stephen Miller as they entered DC's largest rail hub.
items.content: Protesters shouted at Vance, Pete Hegseth and Stephen Miller as they entered DC's largest rail hub.

Vance, along with Stephen Miller and Pete Hegseth, handed out burgers.
Protesters chanted "Free DC!" during the photo opportunity.
Vance defended the use of troops in the area.
Demonstrators protested outside the event.

clusters.title: Massacres in eastern Congo cast doubt on U.S. mediated peace deal
clusters.neutral_headline: Massacres in Eastern Congo Raise Questions About Peace

items.title: Massacres in eastern Congo cast doubt on U.S. mediated peace deal
items.standfirst: Rwanda backed M23 rebels in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo killed hundreds of villagers in July, according to Human Rights Watch, raising doubts about Trump backed peace process.
items.content: Rwanda backed M23 rebels in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo killed hundreds of villagers in July, according to Human Rights Watch, raising doubts about Trump backed peace process.(Image credit: JOSPIN MWISHA)

items.title: At least 140 killed by Rwanda-backed rebels in eastern DR Congo, rights group says
items.standfirst: Human Rights Watch said 141 people, predominantly Hutus, were feared to have been killed in eastern Congo in July in attacks believed to have been carried out by the Rwanda-backed M23 group, the most prominent of the armed groups fighting for control of the region.
items.content: Human Rights Watch said 141 people, predominantly Hutus, were feared to have been killed in eastern Congo in July in attacks believed to have been carried out by the Rwanda-backed M23 group, the most prominent of the armed groups fighting for control of the region.

items.title: DR Congo rebels killed 140 civilians despite peace process, rights group says
items.standfirst: Attacks were carried out in more than a dozen villages last month, Human Rights Watch says.
items.content: Attacks were carried out in more than a dozen villages last month, Human Rights Watch says.

ai_summary: Human Rights Watch reported massacres in eastern Congo by Rwanda-backed rebels.
The attacks occurred in July, killing hundreds of villagers.
The attacks cast doubt on the U.S.-mediated peace deal.
The M23 group is the most prominent armed group in the region.
At least 140 civilians were killed in the attacks.

The strike began on Aug. 16 after…

The strike began on Aug. 16 after…

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants reach ‘tentative’ deal with airline to end strike
items.standfirst: Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwideAir Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job after midnight Saturday, insisting Air Canada had failed to address their demands for higher pay and compensation for unpaid ground work, including during boarding. Continue reading...
items.content: Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwideAir Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job after midnight Saturday, insisting Air Canada had failed to address their demands for higher pay and compensation for unpaid ground work, including during boarding. Continue reading...

items.title: Air Canada and flight attendants reach tentative deal to end strike
items.standfirst: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."
items.content: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."

ai_summary: Air Canada flight attendants reached a tentative labor agreement with the airline.
The agreement ended a strike that began on August 16.
The strike involved approximately 10,000 flight attendants.
The strike caused cancellations affecting 500,000 travelers.
The union advised members to cooperate with the resumption of operations.

clusters.title: Bus crash fire kills dozens of Afghans deported from Iran
clusters.neutral_headline: Bus Crash in Afghanistan Kills Dozens of Deportees

items.title: Bus crash fire kills dozens of Afghans deported from Iran
items.standfirst: Around 80 people have been killed in a bus crash that caught fire in Afghanistan’s Herat province.
items.content: Around 80 people have been killed in a bus crash that caught fire in Afghanistan’s Herat province.

items.title: At least 78 people killed as bus collides with fuel truck in western Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Bus crash kills more than 70 Afghans deported from Iran, including 17 children
items.standfirst: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.
items.content: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.

ai_summary: A bus crash in Afghanistan killed around 80 people.
The bus was carrying Afghans deported from Iran.
The crash involved a collision with a fuel truck.
Seventeen children were among the fatalities.
Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries.

items.title: Family's plea to fugitive dad on the run with children for nearly four years
items.standfirst: The family of a father who disappeared with his three children nearly four years ago in New Zealand have broken their silence to appeal for him to return home.
items.content: The family of a father who disappeared with his three children nearly four years ago in New Zealand have broken their silence to appeal for him to return home.

items.title: Family of NZ fugitive on the run with children pleads for return
items.standfirst: Tom Phillips and his children have been missing since 2021, in a case that has gripped New Zealand.
items.content: Tom Phillips and his children have been missing since 2021, in a case that has gripped New Zealand.

items.title: Family of New Zealand fugitive on the run for almost four years with his children plead for his return
items.standfirst: In a New Zealand television interview, relatives spoke of their anguish since Tom Phillips disappeared with his three children in late 2021The family of a fugitive father who has been hiding for more than three years in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children has pleaded with the man to come home, in some of their first public comments since he vanished.Just before Christmas 2021, Tom Phillips fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a dispute with their mother. Phillips does not have legal custody of his children. Continue reading...
items.content: In a New Zealand television interview, relatives spoke of their anguish since Tom Phillips disappeared with his three children in late 2021The family of a fugitive father who has been hiding for more than three years in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children has pleaded with the man to come home, in some of their first public comments since he vanished.Just before Christmas 2021, Tom Phillips fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a dispute with their mother. Phillips does not have legal custody of his children. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The family of a fugitive father is pleading for his return.
The father disappeared with his three children nearly four years ago.
The family has broken their silence to appeal for his return.
The father, Tom Phillips, does not have legal custody of his children.
The family spoke of their anguish since the disappearance.

clusters.title: Judge declines to unseal grand jury material in Jeffrey Epstein case
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Declines to Unseal Epstein Grand Jury Material

items.title: Judge declines to unseal grand jury material in Jeffrey Epstein case
items.standfirst: A federal judge in New York on Wednesday declined the federal government's request to unseal grand jury material in the Jeffrey Epstein case.
items.content: A federal judge in New York on Wednesday declined the federal government's request to unseal grand jury material in the Jeffrey Epstein case.

items.title: Judge declines to unseal Jeffrey Epstein case grand jury testimony
items.standfirst: A federal judge in New York has denied the Trump administration's attempts to unseal grand jury testimony from the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The judge said the government failed to demonstrate "special circumstances" that would have warranted disclosing the grand jury material, which typically remains sealed. CBS News legal reporter Katrina Kaufman has more.
items.content: A federal judge in New York has denied the Trump administration's attempts to unseal grand jury testimony from the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The judge said the government failed to demonstrate "special circumstances" that would have warranted disclosing the grand jury material, which typically remains sealed.
